reviewText: Informative if you like ak47s

I loved this mini-documentary!  I watched it with my AKM while we were both munching on Doritos, when suddenly my AKM jumped up and yelled, "!  !" (Look!  It's Mikhail!).  Apparently, an AKS-74 on display in one of the Izhmash museum display cases was an old friend of his.  They came off the production line together, and then served together in Afghanistan.  He told me the story about how they once loved the same Tokarev TT-33 before she betrayed them both.  My AKM escaped; the AKS-74 didn't.  Mikhail was sent back to Russia, reconditioned, and put on display.  My AKM defected.  Turns out the safe house they kept him in while deciding his fate was next to my apartment at the time, and we quickly became friends.  When it was clear that the CIA wasn't going to follow through with asylum we bugged out, changed our names, and made a new life.  But he says that even though it brings back bittersweet memories to see where he was born, and painful emotions when seeing his war buddy on display in a museum, he still regrets nothing.
Interesting documentary about the production of the AK series of rifles. It's neat to see the Russian take on the rifle and their opinion on Western rifles.
Very interesting and informative look at the history, production, testing, and usage of the AK-47. Also touches on some of the newer models.
Very Informative.
A fascinating account of the man who invented the AK-47 and the AK-74. This DVD is a rare find about the life and genius of Mikhael Kalishnikov

This AK-47 History Channel DVD is well made and presents the history of the AK-47, up to and including the AK-74.  It discusses how Kalashnikov eventually prevailed with his AK (Automatic Kalashnikov) over other Russian automatic machine guns.
I sure wish this was longer.  Many facts about the history of assault rifles, the designer and the USSR.  I am sure there is more that could have been included,  maybe there will be a Vol. II.
Interesting little video....liked it but for the Russian language.

Very cool video of the factory complex where they build AK rifles.  In Russian with English subtitles.  Some of the subtitles are hard to read as they are overlaid on the original Russian graphics in the presentation.  If you are a fan of the Kalashnikov rifle this video is worth watching.  I especially enjoyed the testing of the rifles portion.

Pretty good for gun enthusiasts and history buffs.  Be advised that this "movie" is entirely in Russian with English subtitles, and appears to be part propaganda film and part infomercial about the AK-47 that one might see on a tour of the factory.  The host is an enthusiastic Russian girl who never misses a chance to remind the viewer that theirs is the best combat rifle in the world.  Most widely manufactured?  Yes.  Most widely exported?  Certainly.  Easy to train conscripts with?  Okay.  Best overall?  Debatable.  The AK-47 is a terrific "spray-and-pray" rifle that you could probably drive a tank over and it'd still shoot, but accuracy and making a soldier more dangerous on the battlefield are two major factors not addressed in this film.
Interesting, must watch

Subtitles aren't normally a problem, but I kept having to hit my pause button to read them before moving on.  The film itself was more style than substance.  The main point I got is how many variations of the original product there have been.  There was no political message -- really just a glorification of a widespread weapon that has certainly killed more people around the world than nuclear ones.

There is a clear and ever present sense of the quintessential soviet propaganda to this as well which is kind of amusing to me. If your into firearms and especially the AK this will likely be a great program for you.

Propoganda, not a documentary.  There is almost NO information provided regarding the history or design evolution (or lack of it) of the weapon.  The program boasts of the superiority of the design and manufacturing processes over those of the West.  Bull!  There are only 2 reasons why the AK-47 and follow-up AK-74 are the most prolific combat firearms in the world: (1) they are cheap, and (2) the manufacturing tolerances are so loose that you can throw them in a mud puddle and still fire them.  It is not because they are especially accurate or well made.  By the way, the propaganda misleadingly mentions the long corrected problem with the M-16 (originally AR-15 built by Armalite Corp., not Colt) in the early Nam period as though it is still an issue.  The problem was a defective extractor spring, not a moisture or dirt issue as a design flaw.  I have fired many configurations of the M-16 (Armalite, M-16, M-16A1, M-16A2, CAR-15,. . . M-4, etc.) in combat conditions in several different countries with the widest of operating conditions, and the platform is a very good one.  That is not to say that the AK platform is not.  I actually prefer the 7.62x39mm round over the 5.56mm, but that is for its greater impact force.  The issue here isn't whether the AK is a superior weapon as the propaganda claims, because it isn't even close.  Ill take a Heckler & Koch (German) any day for normal combat, and a Lapua (Finnish) .300 Win Mag. for sniping.

He told me the story about how they once loved the same Tokarev TT-33 before she betrayed them both.  My AKM escaped; the AKS-74 didn't.  Mikhail was sent back to Russia, reconditioned, and put on display.  My AKM defected.  Turns out the safe house they kept him in while deciding his fate was next to my apartment at the time, and we quickly became friends. Propoganda, not a documentary.  There is almost NO information provided regarding the history or design evolution (or lack of it) of the weapon.  The program boasts of the superiority of the design and manufacturing processes over those of the West.  Bull!  There are only 2 reasons why the AK-47 and follow-up AK-74 are the most prolific combat firearms in the world: (1) they are cheap, and (2) the manufacturing tolerances are so loose that you can throw them in a mud puddle and still fire them.  It is not because they are especially accurate or well made.  By the way, the propaganda misleadingly mentions the long corrected problem with the M-16 (originally AR-15 built by Armalite Corp., not Colt) in the early Nam period as though it is still an issue.  The problem was a defective extractor spring, not a moisture or dirt issue as a design flaw.  I have fired many configurations of the M-16 (Armalite, M-16, M-16A1, M-16A2, CAR-15,. . . M-4, etc.) in combat conditions in several different countries with the widest of operating conditions, and the platform is a very good one.  That is not to say that the AK platform is not.  I actually prefer the 7.62x39mm round over the 5.56mm, but that is for its greater impact force.  The issue here isn't whether the AK is a superior weapon as the propaganda claims, because it isn't even close.  Ill take a Heckler & Koch (German) any day for normal combat, and a Lapua (Finnish) .300 Win Mag. for sniping.
